Do not buy this game.

Many people gave this game a bad review because the many changes in the game formula. Is fair to say that this is not a sequel to Command & Conquer, It is much more like a action strategy spin-off.

That is not the reason why this game is bad, but here are some reasons why you should not buy it:

- Permanent online connection require to play. In the middle of the campaign EA servers went down and now i simply can't play until they decide to go back up. Now i am here, angry, writing a review.

- Requires you to login and input your password every time you start the game.

- Unskippable cutscenes

- Lack of mission variety, is most of the time build troops and walk around the map destroying everything in empty skirmishers style maps. Is really hard to believe that this game was released in the same year that Starcraft 2 came out.

- The new mechanics are really average, there is not much do to. They cut out resource collection, all you do is choose the appropriate MCV to the situation and walk with your troops.

- Units are ultra resilient. It may take minutes of firing to kill an enemy armada. Combat is not fun.

Edit: You also lost the mission progress when the game lose connection.

Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars Review
Command & Conquer 3: Kane's Wrath Review

INTRODUCTION:Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight is a real-time strategy game developed and published by Electronic Arts. This title serves as the official sequel to the critically acclaimed C&C 3: Tiberium Wars  and acts as the final chapter in the decade and a half long Command & Conquer Tiberian franchise.

PLOT (No Spoilers):The story picks up 15 years after the end of Command & Conquer 3: Kane's Wrath. The Scrin has been defeated, Kane has successfully recovered the Tacitus and the Brotherhood of NOD is merely a shadow of its former self. Despite the Scrin's failed invasion, all is not well as Tiberium now spreads in an ever more rapid rate and human extinction is almost inevitable. The game starts with Kane offering the remaining world leaders a solution to this problem.

PROS:+ Return of live action cinematics but...(See CON #1)
+ Good sound effects and voice acting
+ Interesting veterancy system with visual upgrade changes for each level of veterancy
+ Good special effects and graphics (but average art style)
+ Interesting new units

CONS:- Poor costume quality for the live action cutscenes
- No base building
- No resource gathering
- DRM Stacking (Always Online + Log-in requirement every time you start the game)
- Unlock and account level up system that ruins the game's unit availability: (meaning you can't jump to multiplayer immediately because half of your units are locked.)
- Population Cap
- The game is lore deficient, with a rushed and confusing story
- Poorly written and poorly executed attempt to establish “emotional depth” by giving the Commander a wife that most players won't care about.
- Lack of mission variety and the fun stealth missions were completely removed
- No side bar like the old games; the entire UI looks bad as a whole
- Too much deviation from the C&C source material meaning it neither look nor feel like a C&C game
- Ridiculously low damage and high HP for every unit that results in...(See next CON)
- VERY slow paced action
- Pathfinding problems
- Severe balance issues
- Very short campaign time
- Small and poorly designed campaign maps
- The game as a whole feels rushed and cheap

NEUTRAL:+/- The 'Crawler / MCV' unit building system is an interesting idea but it shouldn't have been implemented on an already existing franchise such as C&C because it already has an established (and working) formula.

CONCLUSION:A VERY BAD sequel which stands as an insult to the fans of a 15 year old franchise. In EA's attempt to “innovate,” they failed to see what made the Command and Conquer games fun for a lot of people.

WORTH IT?NO, the game is not worth it. I would not recommend this game to anyone even on a sale, specially if you're a fan of the old games. You're better off buying the previous titles like Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars and its expansion.

FINAL NOTES:I would have been kinder in my criticism of this game if it did not have the Command and Conquer name on it. Tiberian Twilight would have sold better and would have been received better by the community if it was merely a spin-off rather than the finale of the franchise.

reviewText:
An utter abomination of a game that only earns the right to use the C&C logo because of the live action story involving Joe Kucan as Kane.  Seriously, C&C4 completely abandons every core element of what made the Command and Conquer identity in the first place.  #1) Battles take place more in arena venues than true story dictated maps.  #2) Your unit count is so small that you can forget building an army #3) You cannot build base fortresses and your production capabilities are easily lost and recovered meaning you've got nothing important to defend and no ultimate goal in smashing your opponent's key structure. #4) The ingame economy is so simplified and anemic that it removes any remaining strategic decisions so that it becomes impossible to out-produce your opponent. #5) Progress is slow and boring since you must tediously earn experience points in order to unlock better units. #6) The visual language of the unit designs is no longer clear making it very hard to understand why one unit is superior to another, and not only that but all the units are extremely wimpy with little ability to decisevly break through enemy forces.

C&C4 started out as an experimental idea for a cheaply made free-to-play RTS game and was then forcibly upgraded into a C&C game.  The live action story moments are the only thing worth mentioning about this game to anyone with a passing care about the Command Conquer franchise and for that just go to Youtube where you can see it all for free.

What a terrible, unforgiveable waste of time and resources this game is.

reviewText:
Command and Conquer what happened to you. You used to be the king of RTS. Your cheesy live action cut-scenes were the stuff of legend and we eagerly anticipate your every release.
Now what have you done to yourself? No resources, no armies, no bases? What is this? A shadow of what used to be?
YOU ARE NOT COMPANY OF HEROES!
Why can't you stay the way you used to be? We all loved you and cherished every memory of you? Why do you have to cheapen what we have?
Why? WHY? WHY?!

It is difficult for me to articulate my feelings about Command & Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight. All I really know is, I don't like it.

In some misguided attempt by what I can only assume is an ill-informed marketing department somewhere deep in the bowels of the EA mega structure this installment of the Command & Conquer franchise changes everything about the previous games. They even went so far as to remove the live action cut-scenes that, despite being where B-movie stars go to die, had become a benchmark in the industry.

You no longer build bases or harvest Tiberium, instead you get allocated a number of points that can be spent on units, when a unit die you get your points back and can try a new combination. It takes what used to be a very balanced RTS experience and turns it into an entirely micromanagement experience, and not a terribly good one at that.

This is not unlike what you might see in the later Dawn of War games but where Dawn of War balanced it with RPG elements making each unit seem important here you are just sending mindless, faceless entities towards a bunch of other mindless, faceless entities in the hope of beating the map objective before you mind rots from the monotone boredom.

Command & Conquer might be viewed by many as the classic simple RTS, but it was the one that monopolized the best on that approach and it was the franchise that more than any other made the real time strategy genre a force to be reckoned with.

Now it is nothing more a boring mediocre clone of a game, trying to do with all the other cool new RTS's are doing but not doing it nearly as well and losing what made the game special in the first place in the attempt.

It is a sad end for what was once such a proud franchise. The older Command & Conquer games will forever hold a special place in my heart but this makes me hope the series will die before another abomination is released.

reviewText:
This is not your typical C&C by any means, the rumors say that this was EA's attempt to push C&C to eSports, but because market was overwhelmed by MOBAs and other quality RTS games, they decided to slap 4 and ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE story on it to lure in loyal C&C fans, and the final product we have now does look and play exactly like it was initially planned to be. The only reason i give this game a positive rating is because i had a tons of fun and positive memories playing it with my friends in coop/compstomp and just skirmish with AI. If you play this game without thinking about past C&C games, it's actually fine, runs great, plays great, looks great. Let's do a breakdown :

Reasons to buy it ( only if it's on huge sale and you are desperate ) :

- Tons of fun in COOP with friends or vs AI alone.
- Very pretty environmental/map design.
- Sometimes it's very challenging.
- Visuals.
- 5v5 players possible.

Reasons to avoid it and tell me that i am stupid for giving it a positive rating :

- Abysmal plot written by a madman in a few hours. Probably taken from DeviantArt fanfiction section.
- Questionable units design.
- Horrible FMV actors performance.
- There is almost no way to beat campaign alone, it's designed to be beaten in COOP.
- Unit cap.
- Has almost nothing to do with C&C, hence no base building or tiberium harvesting.
- The ending cutscene ( which is the finale of whole C&C series presumably ) is so horrible that you might want to kys after it.
- Most of the super/special weapons feel weak.
- You need to unlock units in order to use them.


If reasons to avoid it don't scare you + it's on a huge sale and you have a friend to play it with - then you might want to get it just for collection and full playthrough with people you know. If you're looking for extra content for it - don't. Game doesn't have mod support, but it does have few custom maps.

But if you want some more good old C&C - don't get it, it's not C&C, it won't be fun for you, infact it might leave you with few dead brain cells, just like me.

reviewText:
I actually quite enjoyed playing this despite the bad publicity it has. Yes, EA do what they typically do and use a name to sell a game that's completely different from what is expected of it. It probably should have been an offshoot instead of a sequel. If you can ignore that then it's not that bad of a game and has no serious technical problems.

The game is basically just dumbed down and casualised RTS that's good for playing for 30 minutes. All the more complex aspects such as base and resource management are thrown away leaving you with the job of looking after 1 master unit, the Crawler. You collect Tiberium crystals to receive upgrade points and when the Crawler is destroyed it respawns at a drop off point. The Defense type can construct buildings but only buildings such as the Obelisk and Nuke/Ion Cannon which require the Crawler to be alive to operate. Support buildings can also be captured but cannot be destroyed.

I completed the campaign and played some skirmishes. The skirmish mode is a little shallow and some extra customization would have made it much better such as increasing the unit limit for games with more players. I can only recommend this if your a true fan of the sries and want to see the last of the Tiberium Saga.  While its not a bad game in its own right it defies a lot of typical conventions that C&C has had since its inception in 1995.

However if we forget that this is a C&C game and judge it on its own merits.  I'll say this, first its a fast paced game and unlike  previous C&C games it requires you to think about using your units right as each unit now has a strength/weakness mechanic more so in this title.

Graphics wise its visual fideltiy is pretty impressive for an RTS game and even though the ammount of units you can have is limited the battles do in fact feel big, which is a plus.

As this is a C&C game you can expect well acted real time cutscenes and these are the most impressive I'vse seen so far.

Now for problems.

One of the major issues is that players can level up outside multiplayer and then take that rank/level into multiplayer, meaning there's no sense of progression and someonne can just anhilate you in multiplayer because you've not unlocked all the units/upgrades.

Bottom line this can be a fun title if you can forget it has anything to do with Command and Conquer, but it also appeals to true fans.  Generic RTS fans may want to avoid this title.  Which is the only reason I can recommend this title.

Out of all of the Command & Conquer games I've played, this is the only one I've ever regretted buying. As it's shown through gameplay, it does NOT resemble the traditional build-up-your-base-and-army aspects seen in most of the previous games (Renegades is an FPS game). reviewText:
I have so many mixed emotions about this game.

One of my biggest beefs with this game is that it's just plain short.  There are only 7 GDI missions,  7 NOD missions, and 3 common missions.  I finished it all in 14 hours.  Not much room in there for story.  The story they did have, and the cutscenes, seem very low budget and thrown together.  No Hollywood actors this time around.  The final cutscene in each campaign is literally the actors standing in front of a white sheet with a drawn picture.  If they had doubled the number of missions, I would be recommending this game.  It seems like they're trying to bring a lot of focus onto multiplayer, but I'm only interested in the single player aspect.

One thing that took a little while to get used to is that they changed the gameplay style.  Previous C&C games have had the formula of building/defending/expanding a base, managing your economy and power, and trying to push out as many units as you can.  In this game, you have a fixed number of points that can be redeemed for units, another set of points for structures, and third set for skill upgrades and expanding your tech tree.  There are no power plants, harvesters, etc.  And if a unit is killed or a structure is lost, you get your points refunded, and can build it again.  A key strategy is to continually move your MCV forward, towards the goal.  This makes most of the maps very linear.  Once you can get past the dramatic difference in play style, the game actually gets enjoyable.  Though some of the time, it just feels like you're filling up your build queue so you can spam the enemy.

With the new all-in-one MCV style, they added something that I thought was not well executed.  Instead of just one kind of MCV, they now have three:  offensive, defensive, and support.  Offensive is mostly for making units.  Defensive is for setting up structures like cannons and bunkers.  Support was totally useless to me, as it's for making repairs and setting up airstrikes.  The reason why this wasn't well executed is that you could only have one MCV at a time.  So you can't be defending a structure and attacking the enemy's MCV at the same time.

reviewText:
Out of all of the Command & Conquer games I've played, this is the only one I've ever regretted buying. As it's shown through gameplay, it does NOT resemble the traditional build-up-your-base-and-army aspects seen in most of the previous games (Renegades is an FPS game). There's a limit on how much units you can use at one time. It's also not a destroy-the-enemy-base game anymore as it's more like a hold down points of the map type of game.

However, the biggest disappointment I found would be the online portion. First, an internet connection is required at all times even if you're not playing online. Second, because there's a level up system which determines how much you can use (and both factions have separate level progresses), it limits a player's choices within the first hours or days of playing. Lastly, playing online can match people unfairly (players may have considerably large level gaps), leading to games where a new player doesn't have the units a higher level player does, especially powerful ones.

If you're a player who has played CnC games throughout the years, it's likely you'll be disappointed with the change in gameplay mechanics. I really don't think this game is worth playing, but that doesn't exactly mean I'm saying don't buy it". Buy it if you want
